newsitem.title: TAIWAN: France to indefinitely freeze arms sales to Taiwan.
newsitem.headline: France to indefinitely freeze arms sales to Taiwan.

text.p: France has indefinitely halted further arms sales to Taiwan in a likely effort to appease China, state radio and newspapers reported on Wednesday.
Planned deals that have not been signed or are still under negotiation, such as the talks on supplying shoulder-launched Mistral missiles, would be stopped, the reports said.
The Independence Morning Post, quoting unidentified senior military officials, said France began the freeze at the end of January and had officially notified Taiwan earlier this month.
The freeze would not affect deals already signed between Taiwan and France, the newspaper said.
Taiwan has negotiated with France for the purchase of new weapons, including Matra Space and Defence Mistral missiles, anti-tank rockets, armoured cars and radar system.
Taiwan's China Times Express newspaper said France's move was aimed at appeasing China, Taiwan's arch rival, before President Jacques Chirac visits Beijing in May.
But the newspaper quoted an unidentified Defence Ministry official from Taiwan as saying that weapon sales from France to Taiwan would continue as long as they were not revealed.
Ministry spokesman Kung Fan-ting, speaking on state radio, said: "It is our principle not to comment on arms deals".

Taiwan has bought six French Lafayette-class frigates, two of which have already been sent to the island. It has also signed a contract for 60 Mirage 2000-5 fighter jets, a deal that drew China's anger.
Beijing retaliated by closing the French consulate in the southern city of Guangzhou and freezing French firms out of lucrative Chinese contracts.

China lifted the freeze in 1994 after Paris agreed that the "one China" term of its diplomatic relations with Beijing obliged it to abandon a policy of arming Taiwan, the last bastion of the exiled Republic of China government.
Taiwan and China split after their civil war ended in 1949. Beijing views Taiwan as a renegade province and has said any move by Taipei to declare independence would lead to an attack.
